title: DSAN 6300 Mini Project Visualizations
text: Investigate U.S. airline performance during November 2023, using data from the Bureau of Transportation Statistics, to better understand operational efficiency, reliability, and patterns influencing delays and cancellations.

title: DSAN 6300 Mini Project Visualizations
text:
Question 1
Find maximal departure delay in minutes for each airline. Sort results from smallest to largest maximum delay. Output airline names and values of the delay.

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
df = pd.read_csv("miniproject_ig294_problem1.csv")

# Sort from smallest to largest maximum delay
df = df.sort_values("Maximum_Delay")

# Identify smallest & largest airlines
min_airline = df.iloc[0]["Airline_Name"]
max_airline = df.iloc[-1]["Airline_Name"]

colors = []
for airline in df["Airline_Name"]:
    if airline == min_airline:
        colors.append("green")   # smallest delay highlight
    elif airline == max_airline:
        colors.append("red")     # largest delay highlight
    else:
        colors.append("lightgray")

plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
bars = plt.barh(df["Airline_Name"], df["Maximum_Delay"], color=colors)

# Add plain numeric labels (no "min")
for bar in bars:
    width = bar.get_width()
    plt.text(width + 10, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2,
             f"{int(width)}", va="center", fontsize=9)

plt.xlabel("Maximum Delay (minutes)")
plt.ylabel("Airline")
plt.title("Maximum Departure Delay by Airline")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 1.png")
plt.show()

title: DSAN 6300 Mini Project Visualizations
text:
Question 2
Find maximal early departures in minutes for each airline. Sort results from largest to smallest. Output airline names.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv("/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem2.csv")
df_sorted = df.sort_values(by="Max_Early_Departure", ascending=False)

plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
bars = plt.barh(df_sorted['Airline_Name'], df_sorted['Max_Early_Departure'], 
                color='skyblue')

plt.gca().invert_yaxis()

for i, (value, airline) in enumerate(zip(df_sorted['Max_Early_Departure'], 
                                         df_sorted['Airline_Name'])):
    plt.text(value + 1, i, str(value), va='center')  # <-- SMALL OFFSET (1)

plt.xlabel("Maximum Early Departure (minutes)")
plt.title("Maximum Early Departure by Airline")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 2.png")
plt.show()

title: DSAN 6300 Mini Project Visualizations
text:
Question 3
Rank days of the week by the number of flights performed by all airlines on that day (1 is the busiest). Output the day of the week names, number of flights and ranks in the rank increasing order

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
df = pd.read_csv('/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem3.csv')

# Ensure ordered by rank
df = df.sort_values('Day_Rank')

plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
bars = plt.barh(df['Day_Name'], df['Total_Flights'], color='skyblue')

# Add labels
for bar, value, rank in zip(bars, df['Total_Flights'], df['Day_Rank']):
    plt.text(bar.get_width() + 20,      # small offset to the right
             bar.get_y() + bar.get_height() / 2,
             f'{value}',
             va='center')

plt.xlabel('Number of Flights')
plt.ylabel('Day')
plt.title('Number of flights by day of the week',fontsize=16)
plt.gca().invert_yaxis()  # highest rank at top
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 3.png")
plt.show()










import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Load CSV data
df = pd.read_csv("/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem3.csv")

# Reorder Day_Name from Monday to Sunday
day_order = ["Monday", "Tuesday", "Wednesday", "Thursday", "Friday", "Saturday", "Sunday"]
df["Day_Name"] = pd.Categorical(df["Day_Name"], categories=day_order, ordered=True)
df = df.sort_values("Day_Name")


# 1. Line plot with markers
plt.figure(figsize=(10,5))
sns.lineplot(
    x="Day_Name",
    y="Total_Flights",
    data=df,
    marker="o",
    markersize=10,
    linewidth=2,
    color="royalblue"
)

# Annotate points
for i, row in df.iterrows():
    plt.text(row["Day_Name"], row["Total_Flights"] + 1000, 
             f'{row["Total_Flights"]}', 
             ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10)

plt.title("Number of Flights by Day of the Week", fontsize=16)
plt.title("Number of Flights by Day of the Week", fontsize=16, pad=25)
plt.xlabel("Day of the Week")
plt.ylabel("Number of Flights")
plt.grid(False)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 3-scatterplot.png")
plt.show()

title: DSAN 6300 Mini Project Visualizations
text:
Question 4
Find the airport that has the highest average departure delay among all airports. Consider 0 minutes delay for flights that departed early. Output one line of results: the airport name, code, and average delay

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv("/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem4.csv")

df['airport_name_modif'] = df['airport_name'].apply(lambda x: x.split(':')[-1].strip())

airport = df.loc[0, "airport_name_modif"]
code = df.loc[0, "airport_code"]
delay = df.loc[0, "average_departure_delay"]

plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4))
plt.axis('off')

# KPI card background
plt.gca().set_facecolor("#f7f7f7")
plt.gcf().patch.set_facecolor("#f7f7f7")

# Title
plt.text(0.5, 0.8, "Airport with the Highest Average Departure delay", 
         ha='center', va='center', fontsize=18, fontweight='bold')

# Airport name
plt.text(0.5, 0.58, f"{airport} ({code})",
         ha='center', va='center', fontsize=14)

# KPI Metric
plt.text(0.5, 0.35, f"{delay:.2f} minutes",
         ha='center', va='center', fontsize=32, color="red", fontweight="bold")

# # Label
# plt.text(0.5, 0.17, "Average Departure Delay", 
#          ha='center', va='center', fontsize=12)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 4.png")
plt.show()


import pandas as p

title: DSAN 6300 Mini Project Visualizations
text:
Question 5
For each airline find an airport where it has the highest average departure delay. Output an airline name, a name of the airport that has the highest average delay, and the value of that average delay.



import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load your CSV
df = pd.read_csv("/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem5.csv")
# Columns expected: Airline_Name, Airport_Name, Average_Departure_Delay

# -------------------------------
# PLOT 1 — Average Delay by Airline
# -------------------------------

airline_delay = (
    df.groupby("Airline_Name")["Average_Departure_Delay"]
    .mean()
    .sort_values()
)

plt.figure(figsize=(14, 8))
plt.barh(airline_delay.index, airline_delay.values, color="skyblue")
plt.title("Average Departure Delay by Airline", fontsize=16)
plt.xlabel("Avg Departure Delay (minutes)",fontsize=16)
plt.ylabel("Airline",fontsize=16)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 5a.png")
plt.show()

# -------------------------------
# PLOT 2 — Average Delay by Airport
# -------------------------------

airport_delay = (
    df.groupby("Airport_Name")["Average_Departure_Delay"]
    .mean()
    .sort_values()
)

plt.figure(figsize=(14, 10))
plt.barh(airport_delay.index, airport_delay.values, color="salmon")
plt.title("Average Departure Delay by Airport (Worst Airport for Each Airline)", fontsize=16)
plt.xlabel("Avg Departure Delay (minutes)", fontsize=16)
plt.ylabel("Airport",fontsize=16)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 5b.png")
plt.show()

title: DSAN 6300 Mini Project Visualizations
text:
Question 6
Check if your dataset has any canceled flights. If it does, what was the most frequent reason for each departure airport? Output airport name, the most frequent reason, and the number of cancelations for that reason

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Read CSV with single column: Cancelled_Flights
df = pd.read_csv("/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem6a.csv")

# Get the total number of cancelled flights (first row)
cancelled_flights = df.loc[0, "Cancelled_Flights"]

plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4))
plt.axis('off')

# KPI card background
plt.gca().set_facecolor("#f7f7f7")
plt.gcf().patch.set_facecolor("#f7f7f7")

# Title
plt.text(0.5, 0.8, "Total Number of Cancelled Flights",
         ha='center', va='center', fontsize=18, fontweight='bold')

# # Subtitle / context
# plt.text(0.5, 0.58, "Total number of cancelled flights",
#          ha='center', va='center', fontsize=14)

# KPI Metric (big number)
plt.text(0.5, 0.35, f"{cancelled_flights:,}",
         ha='center', va='center', fontsize=32, color="red", fontweight="bold")

plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 6 KPI.png")
plt.show()

# pie chart of cancellation reasons 
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load your cancellations CSV
df = pd.read_csv("/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem6b.csv")

# Group by cancellation reason
reason_summary = df.groupby("Most_Frequent_Reason")["Number_Of_Cancellations"].sum()

# Nice colors
colors = ["#FF9999", "#66B2FF", "#99FF99", "#FFCC99", "#C2C2F0"]

plt.figure(figsize=(10, 7))

# Custom autopct function to show % and raw count
def autopct_with_counts(pct):
    total = reason_summary.sum()
    count = int(round(pct * total / 100.0))
    return f"{pct:.1f}% ({count})"

# Pie chart
plt.pie(
    reason_summary,
    labels=reason_summary.index,
    autopct=autopct_with_counts,
    startangle=140,
    colors=colors,
    textprops={'fontsize': 12}
)

plt.title("Breakdown of Cancellation Reasons Across Airports", fontsize=16, fontweight="bold")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 6 pie chart.png")
plt.show()

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
df = pd.read_csv("miniproject_ig294_problem6b.csv")

# Pivot: rows = airport, columns = reason, values = num cancellations
pivot = (
    df.pivot_table(
        index="Airport_Name",
        columns="Most_Frequent_Reason",
        values="Number_Of_Cancellations",
        aggfunc="sum",
        fill_value=0
    )
)

pivot["Total_Cancellations"] = pivot.sum(axis=1)
pivot = pivot.sort_values("Total_Cancellations", ascending=True)
pivot = pivot.drop(columns="Total_Cancellations")


import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Load file
df = pd.read_csv("/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem6b.csv")



top_airports = df.sort_values("Number_Of_Cancellations", ascending=False).head(20)

# --- Plot ---
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 9))
sns.barplot(
    data=top_airports,
    x="Number_Of_Cancellations",
    y="Airport_Name",
    hue="Most_Frequent_Reason",
    dodge=False,                   # ensures one bar per airport
    palette="Set2"
)

plt.title("Top 20 Airports by Most Frequent Cancellation Reason", fontsize=16, fontweight="bold")
plt.xlabel("Number of Cancellations")
plt.ylabel("Airport")
plt.legend(title="Cancellation Reason")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 6 bar chart.png")
plt.show()

title: DSAN 6300 Mini Project Visualizations
text:
Question 7
Build a report that for each day output average number of flights over the preceding 3 days.

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

df = pd.read_csv("/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem7.csv")

plt.figure(figsize=(14,6))

# Plot total flights
plt.plot(df["FlightDate"], df["Flights_Per_Day"], 
         label="Flights Per Day", marker="o")

# Plot rolling average (dashed orange)
plt.plot(df["FlightDate"], df["Avg_Flights_Preceding_3_Days"], 
         label="3-Day Rolling Average", marker="o",
         linewidth=3, linestyle="--", color="orange")

plt.title("Daily Flights and 3-Day Rolling Average", fontsize=16)
plt.xlabel("Flight Date", fontsize=16)
plt.ylabel("Number of Flights",fontsize=16)

# Show every 5th tick on the x-axis
plt.xticks(df["FlightDate"][::5], rotation=45)


# Max flights
max_idx = df["Flights_Per_Day"].idxmax()
plt.annotate(
    f"Max flights: {df['Flights_Per_Day'][max_idx]}\n Occurred on a Sunday",
    xy=(df["FlightDate"][max_idx], df["Flights_Per_Day"][max_idx]),
    xytext=(df["FlightDate"][max_idx], df["Flights_Per_Day"][max_idx] + 1500),
    arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->")
)

# Min flights
min_idx = df["Flights_Per_Day"].idxmin()
plt.annotate(
    f"Min flights: {df['Flights_Per_Day'][min_idx]}\n Occurred on a Thursday",
    xy=(df["FlightDate"][min_idx], df["Flights_Per_Day"][min_idx]),
    xytext=(df["FlightDate"][min_idx], df["Flights_Per_Day"][min_idx] + 2500),
    arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->")
)


plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 7")
plt.show()

Question 1

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Load data
df = pd.read_csv("miniproject_ig294_problem1.csv")

# Sort from smallest to largest maximum delay
df = df.sort_values("Maximum_Delay")

# Identify smallest & largest airlines

max_airline = df.iloc[-1]["Airline_Name"]

colors = []
for airline in df["Airline_Name"]:
    if airline == min_airline:
        colors.append("green")   # smallest delay highlight
    elif airline == max_airline:
        colors.append("red")     # largest delay highlight
    else:
        colors.append("lightgray")

plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
bars = plt.barh(df["Airline_Name"], df["Maximum_Delay"], color=colors)

# Add plain numeric labels (no "min")
for bar in bars:
    width = bar.get_width()
    plt.text(width + 10, bar.get_y() + bar.get_height()/2,
             f"{int(width)}", va="center", fontsize=9)

plt.xlabel("Maximum Delay (minutes)")
plt.ylabel("Airline")
plt.title("Maximum Departure Delay by Airline")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 1.png")
plt.show()

# Pivot: rows = airport, columns = reason, values = num cancellations
pivot = (
    df.pivot_table(
        index="Airport_Name",
        columns="Most_Frequent_Reason",
        values="Number_Of_Cancellations",
        aggfunc="sum",
        fill_value=0
    )
)

pivot["Total_Cancellations"] = pivot.sum(axis=1)
pivot = pivot.sort_values("Total_Cancellations", ascending=True)
pivot = pivot.drop(columns="Total_Cancellations")


import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

# Load file
df = pd.read_csv("/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem6b.csv")



top_airports = df.sort_values("Number_Of_Cancellations", ascending=False).head(20)

# --- Plot ---
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 9))
sns.barplot(
    data=top_airports,
    x="Number_Of_Cancellations",
    y="Airport_Name",
    hue="Most_Frequent_Reason",
    dodge=False,                   # ensures one bar per airport
    palette="Set2"
)

plt.title("Top 20 Airports by Most Frequent Cancellation Reason", fontsize=16, fontweight="bold")
plt.xlabel("Number of Cancellations")
plt.ylabel("Airport")
plt.legend(title="Cancellation Reason")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 6 bar chart.png")
plt.show()

title: DSAN 6300 Mini Project Visualizations
text:
Question 7
Build a report that for each day output average number of flights over the preceding 3 days.

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

df = pd.read_csv("/Users/ishika/Desktop/MS/DSAN 6300/Mini Project/MiniProject/miniproject_ig294_problem7.csv")

plt.figure(figsize=(14,6))

# Plot total flights
plt.plot(df["FlightDate"], df["Flights_Per_Day"], 
         label="Flights Per Day", marker="o")

# Plot rolling average (dashed orange)
plt.plot(df["FlightDate"], df["Avg_Flights_Preceding_3_Days"], 
         label="3-Day Rolling Average", marker="o",
         linewidth=3, linestyle="--", color="orange")

plt.title("Daily Flights and 3-Day Rolling Average", fontsize=16)
plt.xlabel("Flight Date", fontsize=16)
plt.ylabel("Number of Flights",fontsize=16)

# Show every 5th tick on the x-axis
plt.xticks(df["FlightDate"][::5], rotation=45)


# Max flights
max_idx = df["Flights_Per_Day"].idxmax()
plt.annotate(
    f"Max flights: {df['Flights_Per_Day'][max_idx]}\n Occurred on a Sunday",
    xy=(df["FlightDate"][max_idx], df["Flights_Per_Day"][max_idx]),
    xytext=(df["FlightDate"][max_idx], df["Flights_Per_Day"][max_idx] + 1500),
    arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->")
)

# Min flights
min_idx = df["Flights_Per_Day"].idxmin()
plt.annotate(
    f"Min flights: {df['Flights_Per_Day'][min_idx]}\n Occurred on a Thursday",
    xy=(df["FlightDate"][min_idx], df["Flights_Per_Day"][min_idx]),
    xytext=(df["FlightDate"][min_idx], df["Flights_Per_Day"][min_idx] + 2500),
    arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->")
)


plt.legend()
plt.grid(True)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.savefig("Problem 7")
plt.show()

title: Airline Performance in the United States of America: November 2023
text:
Air travel reliability is shaped by many interconnected forces: airline operations, airport congestion, staffing levels, seasonal demand patterns, and even weather.
This project examines U.S. airline performance during November 2023, a month marked by heavy travel activity around Thanksgiving. The analysis aims to understand how well the aviation system functioned under this pressure.
The goals of this exploration are to uncover:

Which airlines and airports are most prone to delays

Where early departures occur and why they matter

How flight volume varies throughout the week

What drives cancellations across airports

How operational patterns evolve over the month

Together, these insights help illuminate how and why flight reliability fluctuates, revealing operational weaknesses and seasonal stress points across the U.S. air transportation system.

title: Airline Performance in the United States of America: November 2023
text:
2.1 Maximum Departure Delay by Airline

American Airlines experienced an extreme maximum delay of roughly 3,518 minutes (~58 hours), whereas Southwest Airlines recorded the lowest maximum delay at about 652 minutes.
This contrast highlights an important operational difference:
Low-cost and regional carriers generally have tighter turnaround schedules and less buffer capacity, which means long delays are far more expensive for them. Every extra minute at the gate can disrupt their entire daily route structure, so they tend to avoid prolonged delays more aggressively.
Large legacy carriers like American Airlines, however, operate complex hub-and-spoke networks. When irregular operations occur (maintenance issues, missed crew connections, aircraft swaps), the ripple effects can accumulate and lead to much longer individual delays, even if such events are rare.

title: Airline Performance in the United States of America: November 2023
text:
2.2 Maximum Early Departures
Early departures may seem harmless, but leaving too early can disrupt passenger connections and scheduling coordination. Comparing the worst early departures gives a sense of how strictly airlines adhere to scheduled departures.

SkyWest shows the largest early departure at around 72 minutes early.
Early departures tend to cluster among regional and commuter airlines, which often operate tight schedules designed around larger hub connections.
Regional carriers sometimes push departures early to maintain tight network timing, especially when feeding into major airline hubs. However, excessive earliness can inconvenience passengers arriving at the gate on time.

title: Airline Performance in the United States of America: November 2023
text:
4.1 Worst Airport Overall
Some airports create more delay risk than others. The KPI below highlights the single worst-performing airport in November 2023.

Concord Padgett Regional shows an average departure delay of 74.19 minutes — significantly higher than most airports. Smaller regional airports may lack robust staffing, runway capacity, or scheduling flexibility, contributing disproportionately to delays.

title: Airline Performance in the United States of America: November 2023
text:
4.2 Worst Airport for Each Airline
After identifying the airlines with the highest average delays, we then examined where those delays occur. Each airline has a unique “worst airport,” meaning the location where it experiences the highest average departure delay. These airports are not necessarily major hubs — many are mid-sized airports with limited infrastructure or seasonal congestion, which can create bottlenecks felt across several airlines.
 
Common high-delay locations include:

Palm Springs International — Handles a large surge of seasonal traffic despite limited runway and gate capacity. Surrounded by mountains, the airport has restricted approach paths, and strong desert crosswinds frequently disrupt operations. These factors cause delays to pile up quickly.
Gainesville Regional — Has limited ground crew and gate availability, so even a single operational delay can cascade. As the primary airport for the University of Florida, Thanksgiving break creates a major travel spike that further strains capacity.
Rick Husband Amarillo International — Located in the Great Plains where strong winds and low visibility are common. The airport also serves regional carriers with tight turnaround schedules, so delays on inbound flights often roll into outbound departures.
Juneau International — One of the most challenging airports in the U.S. due to mountainous terrain and complex approach routes. Winter weather in Alaska like fog, snowfall, and high winds is highly unpredictable in November, making delays almost inevitable.

Interestingly, the airports with the highest delays for multiple airlines are not major hubs, but medium-sized or regional airports. These locations share common characteristics: challenging weather, limited infrastructure, or seasonal congestion. Together, these factors make them highly vulnerable to operational disruptions.

title: Airline Performance in the United States of America: November 2023
text:
5.1 Total Cancellations

The dataset confirms 819 canceled flights during November.

title: Airline Performance in the United States of America: November 2023
section: 5.2 Why Do Airports Cancel Flights? Most Frequent Reasons
text:
5.2 Why Do Airports Cancel Flights? Most Frequent Reasons

Breakdown:

~72% caused by Carrier
~27% caused by Weather
<1% caused by NAS (Air Traffic System)

This means that most cancellations stemmed from airline-controlled factors such as maintenance issues, staffing shortages, and aircraft routing problems.

Top 20 Airports by Cancellation Reason

Airports with the highest cancellations include:

McCarran International

Daniel K. Inouye International

Orlando International

These airports are major leisure destinations or are located in regions prone to seasonal weather issues.
Carrier-related cancellations dominate the system. Weather plays a role but is not the main driver in November. This directly answers our question about which disruptions are within airline control versus external weather or air-traffic constraints.

title: Airline Performance Analysis
text:
Project Objective
This project examines U.S. airline performance during November 2023, using data from the Bureau of Transportation Statistics. The goal is to evaluate how airlines and airports operated during the start of the busy holiday travel season—focusing on delays, cancellations, and day-to-day flight behavior.

title: Airline Performance Analysis
text:
Key Questions

Which airlines and airports demonstrated the strongest reliability?
Where did delays or cancellations cluster, and which carriers were most affected?
How did broader operational patterns such as weekday demand or holiday travel surges—shape overall performance?

title: Airline Performance Analysis
text:
Author
Ishika is a first-year Master’s student in Data Science and Analytics at Georgetown University. This project, completed for DSAN 6300 (Database Systems and SQL), analyzes U.S. airline performance during November 2023 using SQL-generated datasets from the Bureau of Transportation Statistics. All analysis was conducted in Python and presented through a Quarto website, with a narrative storyline designed to highlight key findings and insights. Her academic interests include data visualization, transportation analytics, and storytelling with data.
